Literature Review: Graphene and two-dimensional materials have garnered significant attention in recent years for their potential applications in biosensing due to their unique properties. The high surface area per unit mass of these materials, combined with their ability to harness quantum mechanical attributes, makes them ideal for sensing biomolecules. This review aims to provide an overview of the current state of research in this field, focusing on the sensing of various biomolecules, the influence of defects on sensing performance, and the importance of standardization in calibration of results.
